intro: Sidalcea malviflora subsp. laciniata, commonly known as the fringed checkerbloom, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It belongs to the Malvaceae family, which includes hibiscus and cotton. The plant is characterized by its showy, pink to purple flowers that bloom in late spring to early summer. Its leaves are palmately divided, giving it a distinctive, fern-like appearance. It thrives in moist, well-drained soils and is often found in meadows and along stream banks.
